articles.headline: Putin Urges Plan to Reverse Slide in the Birth Rate
articles.snippet: The Russian president directed Parliament to adopt a 10-year program that would extend maternity leave and subsidize day care.
articles.abstract: The Russian president directed Parliament to adopt a 10-year program that would extend maternity leave and subsidize day care.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, May 10 — President Vladimir V. Putin directed Parliament on Wednesday to adopt a 10-year program to stop the sharp decline in Russia's population, principally by offering financial incentives and subsidies to encourage women to have children.

articles.headline: Tax Benefits to the Rich and Patient
articles.snippet: Policy and research groups in Washington say 80 percent of the tax savings will flow to the top 10 percent of taxpayers.
articles.abstract: Policy and research groups in Washington say 80 percent of the tax savings will flow to the top 10 percent of taxpayers.

articles.headline: Leaving the Wild, and Rather Liking the Change
articles.snippet: A group of tribespeople left the Amazon in Colombia and declared themselves ready to join the modern world.
articles.abstract: A group of tribespeople left the Amazon in Colombia and declared themselves ready to join the modern world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ DEL GUAVIARE, Colombia — Since time immemorial the Nukak-Makú have lived a Stone Age life, roaming across hundreds of miles of isolated and pristine Amazon jungle, killing monkeys with blowguns and scouring the forest floor for berries.

articles.headline: Why the World Doesn't Need Hi-Def DVD's
articles.snippet: Toshiba's high-definition DVD player is the first volley in an absurd format war among the titans of the movie, electronics and computer industries.
articles.abstract: Toshiba's high-definition DVD player is the first volley in an absurd format war among the titans of the movie, electronics and computer industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN did you first become cynical about the electronics industry?

articles.headline: Iraq Set to Unify Security Forces to Battle Chaos
articles.snippet: Iraqi leaders are preparing a major restructuring of the capital's security brigades in hopes of curtailing sectarian tensions.
articles.abstract: Iraqi leaders are preparing a major restructuring of the capital's security brigades in hopes of curtailing sectarian tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 10 — Senior Iraqi leaders are preparing a major restructuring of the capital's security brigades that would place all police officers and paramilitary soldiers under a single commander and in one uniform, in hopes of curtailing the sectarian chaos that is ravaging the city.

articles.headline: 4 Hours a Day, 3 Days a Week
articles.snippet: Long taboo in the mind-sets of European labor unions and governments, part-time work and temp jobs are becoming the richest source of new employment across Europe.
articles.abstract: Long taboo in the mind-sets of European labor unions and governments, part-time work and temp jobs are becoming the richest source of new employment across Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 10 — European labor markets are encrusted and sclerotic, right? Tell that to Jean-Pierre Lemonnier.

articles.headline: Detroit Grapples With a New Era: The Not-So-Big 3
articles.snippet: Asian car companies have moved squarely into the front yard of the capital of American automotive dominance.
articles.abstract: Asian car companies have moved squarely into the front yard of the capital of American automotive dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, May 10 — Fans of the Detroit Red Wings hockey team have booed plenty of opposing teams over the years at Joe Louis Arena, but last month they let loose at another traditional Detroit opponent: Toyota. What set them off was a new Toyota FJ sport utility vehicle that circled the ice during the second intermission of an April 11 game between Detroit and Edmonton.

articles.headline: Fed Raises Rates Again but Clouds Next Move
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates again on Wednesday, its 16th increase in two years, and gave itself room to raise them again in June.     As expected, the central bank nudged up the federal funds rate on overnight loans betwee...
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates again on Wednesday, its 16th increase in two years, and gave itself room to raise them again in June.     As expected, the central bank nudged up the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks another quarter-point, to 5 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 10 - The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates again on Wednesday, its 16th increase in two years, and gave itself room to raise them again in June.

articles.headline: Detroit Grapples With a New Era: The Not-So-Big 3
articles.snippet: Fans of the Detroit Red Wings hockey team have booed plenty of opposing teams over the years at Joe Louis Arena, but last month they let loose at another traditional Detroit opponent: Toyota. What set them off was a new Toyota FJ sport utility veh...
articles.abstract: Fans of the Detroit Red Wings hockey team have booed plenty of opposing teams over the years at Joe Louis Arena, but last month they let loose at another traditional Detroit opponent: Toyota. What set them off was a new Toyota FJ sport utility vehicle that circled the ice during the second intermission of an April 11 game between Detroit and Edmonton.      The outburst showed how the Motor City is still having trouble adjusting to a new reality here: the Asian car companies that Detroit once vowed to vanquish have moved squarely into the front yard of the capital of American automotive dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, May 10 - Fans of the Detroit Red Wings hockey team have booed plenty of opposing teams over the years at Joe Louis Arena, but last month they let loose at another traditional Detroit opponent: Toyota. What set them off was a new Toyota FJ sport utility vehicle that circled the ice during the second intermission of an April 11 game between Detroit and Edmonton.

articles.headline: Leaving the Wild, and Rather Liking the Change
articles.snippet: Since time immemorial the Nukak-Makú have lived a Stone Age life, roaming across hundreds of miles of isolated and pristine Amazon jungle, killing monkeys with blowguns and scouring the forest floor for berries.     But recently, and rather myster...
articles.abstract: Since time immemorial the Nukak-Makú have lived a Stone Age life, roaming across hundreds of miles of isolated and pristine Amazon jungle, killing monkeys with blowguns and scouring the forest floor for berries.     But recently, and rather mysteriously, a group of nearly 80 wandered out of the wilderness, half-naked, a gaggle of children and pet monkeys in tow, and declared themselves ready to join the modern world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ DEL GUAVIARE, Colombia - Since time immemorial the Nukak-Makú have lived a Stone Age life, roaming across hundreds of miles of isolated and pristine Amazon jungle, killing monkeys with blowguns and scouring the forest floor for berries.

articles.headline: 4 Hours a Day, 3 Days a Week
articles.snippet: European labor markets are encrusted and sclerotic, right? Tell that to Jean-Pierre Lemonnier.     Mr. Lemonnier is out in front on a seismic shift in the way Europeans work, one that is provoking the rapid decline of the traditional full-time job...
articles.abstract: European labor markets are encrusted and sclerotic, right? Tell that to Jean-Pierre Lemonnier.     Mr. Lemonnier is out in front on a seismic shift in the way Europeans work, one that is provoking the rapid decline of the traditional full-time job. Long taboo in the mind-sets of European labor unions and governments, part-time work and temporary jobs are becoming by far the richest source of new employment across Europe. ''There's a need for flexibility,'' said Mr. Lemonnier, 47, the president of Manpower France, the temporary staffing company. ''Firing, on economic grounds, in a company with more than nine people, is extremely complicated. So temporary work is the simplest solution for the companies.''
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 10 - European labor markets are encrusted and sclerotic, right? Tell that to Jean-Pierre Lemonnier.

articles.headline: Iraq Set to Unify Security Forces to Battle Chaos
articles.snippet: Senior Iraqi leaders are preparing a major restructuring of the capital's security brigades that would place all police officers and paramilitary soldiers under a single commander and in one uniform, in hopes of curtailing the sectarian chaos that...
articles.abstract: Senior Iraqi leaders are preparing a major restructuring of the capital's security brigades that would place all police officers and paramilitary soldiers under a single commander and in one uniform, in hopes of curtailing the sectarian chaos that is ravaging the city.     The reorganization calls for a substantially reduced presence of American soldiers on the capital's streets, although not necessarily in their numbers nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 10 - Senior Iraqi leaders are preparing a major restructuring of the capital's security brigades that would place all police officers and paramilitary soldiers under a single commander and in one uniform, in hopes of curtailing the sectarian chaos that is ravaging the city.

articles.headline: Putin Urges Plan to Reverse Slide in the Birth Rate
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin directed Parliament on Wednesday to adopt a 10-year program to stop the sharp decline in Russia's population, principally by offering financial incentives and subsidies to encourage women to have children.     Mr. Putin...
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin directed Parliament on Wednesday to adopt a 10-year program to stop the sharp decline in Russia's population, principally by offering financial incentives and subsidies to encourage women to have children.     Mr. Putin's instructions, issued to a compliant Parliament that follows his orders almost without fail, formed the center of his annual address and signaled a new Kremlin determination to confront a problem that demographers have warned endangers the future of the Russian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, May 10 - President Vladimir V. Putin directed Parliament on Wednesday to adopt a 10-year program to stop the sharp decline in Russia's population, principally by offering financial incentives and subsidies to encourage women to have children.

articles.headline: Tax Benefits to the Rich and Patient
articles.snippet: As what may be the last major tax-cut bill from the Bush administration nears final approval in Congress, studies show that most of the benefits will flow to high-income Americans.     The Tax Policy Center, a nonprofit venture of the Urban Instit...
articles.abstract: As what may be the last major tax-cut bill from the Bush administration nears final approval in Congress, studies show that most of the benefits will flow to high-income Americans.     The Tax Policy Center, a nonprofit venture of the Urban Institute and the Brookings Institution, two policy and research groups in Washington, estimated yesterday that 80 percent of the tax savings would flow to the top 10 percent of taxpayers and that almost a fifth of the benefits will go to the top one-tenth of 1 percent.

articles.headline: U.S. Won't Press China Over Yuan
articles.snippet: The Bush administration said on Wednesday that although it was ''extremely dissatisfied'' with China's refusal to allow its currency to fluctuate more freely, it would not cite China as a currency manipulator and provoke a confrontation over the i...
articles.abstract: The Bush administration said on Wednesday that although it was ''extremely dissatisfied'' with China's refusal to allow its currency to fluctuate more freely, it would not cite China as a currency manipulator and provoke a confrontation over the issue.     The administration's announcement, made by Treasury Secretary John W. Snow in compliance with a 1988 law requiring semiannual appraisals of exchange rate issues, was attacked by an array of critics who say that China engages in unfair trade practices by keeping the value of its currency artificially low.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 10 - The Bush administration said on Wednesday that although it was "extremely dissatisfied" with China's refusal to allow its currency to fluctuate more freely, it would not cite China as a currency manipulator and provoke a confrontation over the issue.

articles.headline: Why the World Doesn't Need Hi-Def DVD's
articles.snippet: WHEN did you first become cynical about the electronics industry?     Was it when VHS went out of style, and you had to buy all your movies again on DVD? Was it the time(s) you never got the rebate you mailed away for? Or was it when your computer...
articles.abstract: WHEN did you first become cynical about the electronics industry?     Was it when VHS went out of style, and you had to buy all your movies again on DVD? Was it the time(s) you never got the rebate you mailed away for? Or was it when your computer's 90-day warranty expired, and the thing croaked two days later?
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN did you first become cynical about the electronics industry?
